conclusion: Analyze the P-V diagram of the Stirling cycle, focusing on transitions from state C to state D.
The image shows a P-V diagram of a Stirling cycle with states A, B, C, and D. A→B and C→D are isothermal; B→C and D→A are adiabatic.
A→B is isothermal, so the number of molecules colliding with the unit area of the wall per unit time is constant.
B→C is adiabatic, resulting in a change in the number of collisions per unit area.
C→D is isothermal, so the number of molecules colliding with the unit area of the wall per unit time remains constant.
Since C→D is isothermal, the number of collisions per unit area remains unchanged from state C to state D.
The number of molecules colliding with the unit area of the wall per unit time remains unchanged from state C to state D.
